Row.Text: The first of {1_LeaderName}'s Treasure Convoys has just reached their port safely. This is a step down the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_EXPLORATION_ECONOMIC_NAME} Legacy Path for them; if we hope to succeed, we must establish our own Distant Lands settlements.

Our operatives report that {2_LeaderName} has established the settlement of {1_City} in Distant Lands. They may make pursuing {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_EXPLORATION_ECONOMIC_NAME} and {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_EXPLORATION_MILITARY_NAME} Legacy Paths more difficult. We must stay vigilant — rivalry can be fertile ground for war.

Another religion has taken root in {1_City} in Distant Lands, the populace rejecting the influence of our own priests. If we bring them back to the fold, we can continue down the {LOC_LEGACY_PATH_EXPLORATION_MILITARY_NAME} Legacy Path.
Missionaries from abroad have captivated the inhabitants of {1_City} — an ill portent. If we lose our people's hearts, we may lose more.

Many soldiers have pledged their lives to our empire, but we lack the Commanders to lead them. In addition to the amount of Units our Army Commanders can hold, we will only be able to maintain {1_value} Land Units at the start of the next Age. Without more Army Commanders, we will lose {2_lostunits} Land {2_lostunits: plural 1?Unit; other?Units;} when the Age ends.

Many ships have pledged themselves to our empire, but we lack the Commanders to lead them. At the start of the next Age, we will only be able to maintain as many Naval Units as our Fleet Commanders can hold. Without more Fleet Commanders, we will lose {1_lostunits} Naval {1_lostunits: plural 1?Unit; other?Units;} when the Age ends.
